You may be amazed at what the child notices: the different tones in birdsong, the pattern of shadow on the ground, the smell of earth vs. grass, the texture difference between bark and leaf. This is mindfulness practice grounded in Montessori sensorial training. The nature journal entry becomes a beautiful record of one moment, fully experienced.

title: Reading Comprehension — Answering Questions About a Passage
description: The child reads a short non-fiction passage independently and answers comprehension questions: identifying the main idea, supporting details, vocabulary, and making inferences. This assesses and strengthens reading comprehension skills.
instructions:
1. 'Good readers do not just read words — they UNDERSTAND what they read. Today you will show how well you comprehend!'
2. Present a short non-fiction passage (4-6 paragraphs) on a topic the child has studied: the digestive system, a country, an animal, or the water cycle.
3. The child reads it independently (or with minimal help).
4. Answer questions:
   - Main idea: 'What is this passage mostly about?'
   - Details: 'Name two facts you learned.'
   - Vocabulary: 'What does [word] mean in this passage?'
   - Inference: 'Why do you think...?'
   - Connection: 'How does this connect to something you already know?'
5. The child writes answers in complete sentences.
6. Review together: 'How did you figure that out?'

slides.heading: Reading Comprehension
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! This slide is like the cover of our special book for today. It tells us we are going to practice being super readers who really understand what they read, like a detective finding clues!

slides.setup_instructions: Print a non-fiction passage at the child's reading level. Write 5-6 comprehension questions at different levels.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these fun things we get to use for our reading adventure today! We have a story to read, some questions to answer, and paper and a pencil to write our smart answers. If you want, you can also use a highlighter to mark important parts of the story, like finding treasure! Ask your grown-up to help you get everything ready.

slides.text: 'Reading is not just saying the words — it is UNDERSTANDING the ideas. Today you will read a passage and show me how deeply you understand it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This first step is super important! It means that reading isn't just about saying the words, it's about knowing what those words mean inside your brain. Today, we'll read a story and show how well we can understand all the cool things it tells us.

slides.text: 'Read the passage all the way through once, just to understand it. Then read it again more carefully — this time, you can highlight or underline important information.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's read our story! First, read it all the way through so you get the general idea, like taking a quick peek. Then, read it again more slowly and carefully, and if you see something really interesting, you can use your highlighter to mark it, like putting a star next to it!

slides.text: 'Now answer the questions. For each one, find the EVIDENCE in the text — the sentences that support your answer. Point to where you found the information.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time to be a reading detective! For each question, you need to find the answer right in the story. Look carefully at the words in the story and point to the sentence that tells you the answer. That's called finding the evidence!

slides.text: 'Some questions ask what the text SAYS directly. Others ask you to INFER — to figure out something the text does not say directly, using clues. Both are important!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Some questions are easy peasy, and the answer is right there in the story. Other questions are like a little puzzle! The story gives you clues, and you have to use your thinking cap to figure out the answer, even if it's not written down exactly.

slides.prompt: Read the passage independently. Answer all comprehension questions in complete sentences. Use evidence from the text to support your answers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You read the story all by yourself and answered all the questions. You used the words in the story to help you write your answers in complete sentences. You are such a strong reader!

slides.text: 'You read, understood, and proved your understanding with evidence! That is exactly what strong readers do — they think WHILE they read and can explain what they learned.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a non-fiction passage independently and answer literal, vocabulary, inferential, and connection questions with text evidence?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You are an amazing reader! You read the story, you understood it, and you even showed me where you found the answers. That’s exactly what super smart readers do – they think about what they read and can tell us all about it!

parent_notes: Reading comprehension assessment at this point in the year shows you exactly where the child stands as they prepare for elementary. The five question types (main idea, details, vocabulary, inference, connection) represent a progression from literal understanding to higher-order thinking. If the child struggles with inference questions ('Why do you think the author said...?'), model your own thinking: 'Well, the text says ___, and I know ___, so I think ___.' This 'thinking aloud' teaches the child how skilled readers process text. Use a passage about a familiar topic (something they have studied this year) so background knowledge supports comprehension. The goal is not a grade but a portrait of the child's reading strengths and areas for growth.

title: Math Review — Comprehensive Assessment Through Stations
description: The child rotates through 5 math stations, each covering a key area: number sense, addition/subtraction, multiplication/division, fractions, and geometry. This serves as a joyful, hands-on review of the entire year's math curriculum.
instructions:
1. 'Today is a math celebration! You will visit 5 stations to show everything you know.'
2. Station 1 — Number Sense: Read, write, and order numbers to 9,999. Build a 4-digit number with the stamp game.
3. Station 2 — Addition/Subtraction: Solve 3 problems (including 4-digit addition with carrying).
4. Station 3 — Multiplication/Division: Solve 2 multiplication and 2 division problems.
5. Station 4 — Fractions: Identify, compare, and find equivalent fractions with insets.
6. Station 5 — Geometry: Name shapes, identify angle types, find lines of symmetry.
7. 5-7 minutes per station. Record answers.
8. Celebrate mastery!
materials_needed: Geometric shapes and right angle tester

slides.heading: Math Review Stations
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Math Review Stations" and "Celebrating Everything You Know!" That means today is a super special day where we get to show off all the cool math things we've learned this whole year. It's like a party for your brain!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up 5 stations around the room, each with materials and problem cards. Label each station clearly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these fun things we get to play with for our math stations! We have a stamp game to build big numbers, special shapes for fractions, and even shapes for geometry. We also have little counters and cards with problems, and paper and a pencil to write down our super smart answers. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these treasures so we can start our adventure!

slides.text: 'Today is a math CELEBRATION — you will visit 5 stations to show all the amazing math you have learned this year!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready, because today is a math celebration! We're going to visit five different spots, and at each one, you'll get to show how much you know about numbers, adding, subtracting, and so much more. It's your time to shine and show off all your super math skills!

slides.text: 'Station 1: Number Sense — read, write, and order big numbers. Station 2: Addition and Subtraction — solve problems, including big ones with carrying!'
slides.mascot_explanation: In the first station, we'll practice reading and writing big numbers, and even build them with stamps! Then, in the second station, we'll be math detectives solving addition and subtraction puzzles, even the tricky ones where we have to carry over numbers. You're going to be so amazing!

slides.text: 'Station 3: Multiplication and Division — use your facts and materials. Station 4: Fractions — name, compare, and find equivalents.'
slides.mascot_explanation: For station three, we'll use our super multiplication and division powers to solve problems. And in station four, we'll play with special fraction shapes to see how they fit together and compare them. You're doing so great, keep up the awesome work!

slides.text: 'Station 5: Geometry — name shapes, identify angles, find symmetry. Spend about 5 minutes at each station. Record your work!'
slides.mascot_explanation: At the last station, station five, we'll look at all sorts of shapes, talk about their pointy corners, and even find secret lines that make them the same on both sides! We'll spend a little bit of time at each spot, and remember to write down your answers so we can see all your hard work.

slides.prompt: Rotate through all 5 math stations. Complete the activities at each one. Use materials whenever you want. Record all your work on paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we get to go on a math adventure to five different stations! At each one, you’ll get to do fun math activities and use all the cool tools we have. Just do your best at each station, and remember to write down your answers on your paper. You can do this!

slides.text: 'Look at everything you can do in math! Numbers, operations, fractions, and geometry — you have built an incredible mathematical foundation this year!'
slides.mastery_check: Which areas show strong mastery? Which areas would benefit from continued practice? This serves as an informal year-end math assessment.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at you go! You worked so hard at all five stations, and you learned so much this year. You’re a math superstar with numbers, adding, subtracting, fractions, and shapes. Let's cheer for all the amazing math things you know how to do!

parent_notes: The station rotation format makes assessment feel like a celebration rather than a test. The child demonstrates mastery through doing, not through anxiety-producing test conditions. Each station can be adjusted to the child's level — if 4-digit addition is too challenging, use 3-digit. If multiplication with the board is needed, provide the board. The goal is to document what the child CAN do, not what they cannot. Take notes on each station: what the child completes confidently, where they need materials, and where they struggle. This information guides summer activities and the transition to elementary. Celebrate specific growth: 'In September you were counting to 100, and now you are adding four-digit numbers! That is incredible growth.'

title: The Scientific Method — Conducting the Experiment
description: The child conducts the experiment planned earlier this week, following the scientific method: testing the hypothesis, recording observations, and drawing a conclusion. This is a complete, hands-on science investigation.
instructions:
1. Review: 'What was your question? What was your hypothesis?'
2. Set up the experiment with all planned materials.
3. 'Follow your procedure step by step. Change only ONE thing (the variable). Keep everything else the same.'
4. Observe and record: 'What is happening? Write down everything you see, hear, feel, and measure.'
5. If the experiment has a waiting period, set it up and record initial observations.
6. Analyze: 'What happened? Was your hypothesis correct?'
7. Conclusion: 'I learned that ___ because ___. My hypothesis was right/wrong because ___.'
8. 'Scientists are not disappointed when hypotheses are wrong — they learned something new!'
materials_needed: All materials for the planned experiment

slides.heading: Conducting Your Experiment
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to do a super fun science experiment today! We'll be like real scientists and test our smart guess to see if it's right. Get ready to discover something new!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all materials from the experiment plan. Set up the experiment space. Have the recording sheet ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need lots of things for our experiment! We have our experiment stuff, a paper to write on, a pencil, some tools to measure, a camera to take pictures, and a timer to count the minutes. Ask your grown-up to help you find all of these so we can start our science adventure!

slides.text: 'Your question was: [question]. Your hypothesis was: [hypothesis]. Now it is time to FIND OUT if you were right! Let's set up your experiment.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember the big question we had about our experiment? And remember what we guessed might happen? Well, it's time to find out if our guess was right! Let's get everything ready to test it out.

slides.text: 'Follow your procedure exactly. The most important rule: change only ONE thing. Everything else stays the same. This is called a FAIR TEST.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we need to be super careful and follow our plan, step-by-step. The most important thing is to only change one little thing at a time, and keep everything else the same. This makes sure our test is fair, like a game where everyone plays by the same rules!

slides.text: 'OBSERVE carefully. Write down everything that happens. Measure when you can. Draw what you see. A good scientist records everything!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be super observers! Watch closely and listen carefully to everything happening in our experiment. We need to write down or draw everything we see, hear, and feel. Being a good scientist means noticing all the little details!

slides.text: 'Now ANALYZE your results. What happened? Was your hypothesis correct? Write your CONCLUSION: I learned that ___ because ___.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to be detectives and look at all the cool things we saw! What happened in our experiment? Was our guess correct? We'll write down what we learned and if our guess was right or wrong.

slides.prompt: Conduct your experiment following the procedure. Record all observations with drawings and words. Write your conclusion. Was your hypothesis correct?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we tell everyone what we discovered! We'll say, "I learned that..." and explain why. Then we'll say if our guess was right or wrong, and why we think that. You did such a great job doing all this!

slides.text: 'You just completed a REAL scientific investigation! You asked a question, made a prediction, tested it, and drew a conclusion. That is exactly what scientists do!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child conduct a fair test, record observations accurately, and draw a logical conclusion that references the hypothesis?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did a real science experiment, just like a grown-up scientist! You asked a question, made a guess, tested it out, and figured out what happened. That's amazing, and you should be super proud of yourself!

parent_notes: The experiment is the child's first complete scientific investigation. Excellent simple experiments include: Does a paper airplane fly farther with large or small wings? (variable: wing size), Does a plant lean toward light? (variable: light direction — place a plant near a window and observe over days), Does warm water dissolve sugar faster than cold water? (variable: temperature), Do ramps of different heights make a ball roll farther? (variable: ramp height). The key concept is the FAIR TEST: change only one variable. If you change two things, you cannot know which one caused the result. If the hypothesis was wrong, celebrate: 'That is WONDERFUL! You learned something unexpected. Many of the greatest scientific discoveries happened when hypotheses were wrong!' Document the experiment with photos for the portfolio.

title: Portfolio Art Piece — Creating a Self-Portrait
description: The child creates a detailed self-portrait as a capstone art piece for the year-end portfolio. They observe themselves carefully in a mirror and draw with attention to proportion, features, and expression.
instructions:
1. 'Artists throughout history have painted SELF-PORTRAITS — pictures of themselves. Today you create yours!'
2. Set up a mirror at eye level.
3. Observe: 'Look at the shape of your face. Where are your eyes — in the middle! Notice your eyebrows, nose, mouth. What makes YOUR face unique?'
4. Teach basic proportions: eyes are in the middle of the head, nose halfway between eyes and chin, mouth halfway between nose and chin.
5. Sketch lightly first: face shape, then features.
6. Add color: skin tone (mix carefully!), eye color, hair color and texture.
7. Add a background that represents who you are.
8. Sign and date the portrait.
materials_needed: Optional: previous self-portrait from earlier in the year for comparison

slides.heading: Self-Portrait
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make a special picture today, a picture of YOU! It's called a self-portrait, and it's like a super-special art project that shows everyone how amazing you are.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a mirror at the child's eye level. Provide good quality paper and a range of coloring materials. Find a well-lit workspace.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our art supplies ready for our self-portrait! We need a mirror so we can see our own face, some nice paper to draw on, a pencil to make our first lines, and colors like crayons or paint to make it beautiful. Ask a grown-up to help you find these things!

slides.text: 'Famous artists like Frida Kahlo, Vincent van Gogh, and Rembrandt all painted SELF-PORTRAITS. A self-portrait shows the world who you are. Today you create yours!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Long, long ago, very famous artists made pictures of themselves, just like we're going to do! These pictures are called self-portraits, and they help us see who the artist is. Today, you get to be the artist and make a picture of yourself!

slides.text: 'Look in the mirror carefully. Your eyes are in the MIDDLE of your head, not near the top! Your nose is halfway between your eyes and chin. Really LOOK at yourself.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look super close in the mirror. See how your eyes are right in the middle of your head? Your nose is down a little bit from your eyes, and your mouth is under your nose. Look carefully at where everything is on your face!

slides.text: 'Sketch the shape of your face first — oval, round, or somewhere in between. Then add your eyes, nose, and mouth in the right places. Look at the mirror, draw, look again.'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we'll draw the shape of your head, like an oval or a circle. Then, we'll draw your eyes, nose, and mouth right where you saw them in the mirror. Look at the mirror, draw a little, then look again to make sure it's just right!

slides.text: 'Now add color. For skin tone, mix carefully — your skin is a beautiful, unique color. Add your hair color and texture. Then add a background that shows something about who you are.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to add all the wonderful colors! We'll pick colors for your skin, maybe mixing them to be just like yours, and colors for your hair. Then, you can draw a fun background that tells us something special about you!

slides.prompt: Create your self-portrait. Look carefully in the mirror as you draw. Pay attention to proportion, color, and detail. Add a background that represents you. Sign and date it.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part – you get to make your whole self-portrait now! Keep looking at the mirror and drawing all the parts of your face, then add your special background. When you're all done, write your name and the date, like a real artist!

slides.text: 'This is YOU — captured by your own hand! Your self-portrait shows both what you LOOK like and who you ARE. It is a perfect way to remember this moment in your life.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a recognizable self-portrait with appropriate facial proportions, accurate coloring, and personal expression?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your amazing picture! You made a portrait of YOU, and it looks just like you! You showed us your face and even a little bit of your personality in your special background. You did such a wonderful job creating your self-portrait!

parent_notes: The self-portrait is a profound year-end activity. Artistically, it requires observation (looking at the mirror), proportion (placing features correctly), color mixing (skin tone), and personal expression (background choices). Emotionally, it is an act of self-regard — the child looks at themselves carefully and says, 'I am worth drawing.' If you have a self-portrait from earlier in the year (or even a first-day-of-school drawing), comparing the two shows dramatic growth in artistic ability and self-perception. The background choice is revealing: a child surrounded by books, animals, nature, or family is telling you who they are. Frame or display this self-portrait prominently. Consider Frida Kahlo as a reference — her self-portraits are powerful, distinctive, and accessible to children.

title: Nature Journal Completion — Assembling the Final Nature Journal
description: The child assembles the complete nature journal: pressed flowers (begun earlier), leaf rubbings, observation drawings, nature art photos, multi-sensory observations, and the environmental pledge. This becomes a lasting portfolio piece.
instructions:
1. 'Your nature journal is almost complete! Today we put it all together.'
2. Check pressed flowers: if dry, carefully mount in the journal with tape or glue.
3. Arrange all entries in order: collection page, leaf rubbings, observation drawings, nature art photo, sensory observation page, environmental pledge.
4. Add a cover page: 'Nature Journal by [child's name], [date].'
5. Add a table of contents.
6. Write a final reflection: 'What I learned about nature this year...'
7. Bind the journal (hole-punch with ribbon, or place in a folder).
8. 'This journal captures your connection to the natural world.'
materials_needed: All nature journal pages from the week

slides.heading: Nature Journal
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to finish our special Nature Journal today. It's like a book all about the amazing things we found outside!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all nature journal entries from the week. Check on pressed flowers. Set up a binding station.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need to make our journal super special. We have all our pages from our nature adventures, pretty pressed flowers, sticky tape or glue, paper for the front, a hole puncher with ribbon to tie it all up, and pencils for writing. Can you help find all these things with a grown-up?

slides.text: 'All week you have been observing, drawing, collecting, and writing about nature. Now let's assemble everything into your finished NATURE JOURNAL!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We've done so much exploring and drawing this week, haven't we? Now it's time to put all those wonderful nature discoveries together into our very own book!

slides.text: 'First, check your pressed flowers. If they are dry and flat, carefully mount them in the journal using small pieces of tape. Label each one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember those pretty flowers we pressed? Let's check if they're all dry and flat. If they are, we can carefully stick them onto a page in our journal with tape.

slides.text: 'Arrange your pages in order. Create a cover page with the title, your name, and the date. Make a table of contents so a reader can find each section.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to be the boss of our journal! Let's put all our pages in the right order, make a cool cover page with our name on it, and add a page at the beginning that tells us what's inside each part.

slides.text: 'Write a final reflection: What did you learn about nature this week? What surprised you? What do you want to explore more? Then bind your journal!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It’s time to think about all the fun we had! Let's write down what we learned about nature and what made us go "Wow!" Then we'll tie our journal all together so it stays neat.

slides.prompt: Assemble your complete nature journal: mount specimens, arrange pages, create cover and table of contents, write your reflection, and bind. Read through the whole journal when finished.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to build our whole nature journal right now! We'll put all the pages in, make a cover, write our thoughts, and tie it up tight. Then we'll flip through it to see all our amazing nature work!

slides.text: 'Your nature journal is a record of how you see the natural world — through your eyes, ears, nose, fingers, and heart. Scientists and artists treasure their nature journals. Now you have one too.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child assemble a complete, organized nature journal with multiple types of entries, a cover, and a reflective conclusion?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this beautiful book you made! It shows everyone how you see and feel about nature, just like real scientists and artists do. You made a treasure!

parent_notes: The completed nature journal is one of the most beautiful portfolio pieces of the entire year. It demonstrates observation skills, scientific vocabulary, artistic ability, and environmental awareness all in one document. If the pressed flowers are not ready yet (they typically need 1-2 weeks), leave space in the journal and add them later. The final reflection is important — it asks the child to articulate what they learned and what they want to learn next, developing metacognitive awareness. Consider continuing the nature journal over the summer as a family activity — a weekly nature observation keeps science, art, and writing skills active during the break. Nature journals by Maria Sibylla Merian, Beatrix Potter, and John Muir are wonderful inspirations.

title: Year-End Reading Celebration — Reading Aloud to the Family
description: The child selects a favorite passage or story to read aloud to the family, demonstrating reading fluency, expression, and confidence. This celebrates the child's growth as a reader throughout the year.
instructions:
1. 'Today is a READING CELEBRATION! You will read aloud to your family, just like a storyteller.'
2. The child selects what to read: a favorite picture book, a passage from their chapter book, a poem they wrote, or their own authored story.
3. Practice: read through once for fluency. Coach on expression: 'Make your voice match the feeling. Loud when it is exciting! Soft when it is mysterious.'
4. Gather the family as audience.
5. The child reads aloud with expression, showing illustrations if applicable.
6. Audience responds with genuine appreciation.
7. Reflect: 'How does it feel to read confidently? You could not do this at the beginning of the year!'

slides.heading: Reading Celebration
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Reading Celebration!" That means today is a super special day where you get to be the star reader and share something fun with your family. We're going to have a party for how much you've learned!

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child choose their reading material. Set up a cozy reading area with audience seating.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need a couple of things for our celebration! First, you need to pick a book or a story that you really, really love. Then, let's find a comfy spot, like a cozy chair or a special blanket on the floor, where you can sit and read to everyone.

slides.text: 'Today YOU are the reader! Choose your favorite thing to read aloud: a book, a poem you wrote, or a story you wrote. Something that matters to you.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to pick your special story! Think about your favorite book, or maybe a poem you wrote, or even a story you made up all by yourself. Choose the one that makes your heart happy to read!

slides.text: 'Let's practice. Read it through once. Think about your voice: when should it be loud or soft? Fast or slow? Happy or serious? Your voice tells the story!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's practice reading your story a little bit. Read it through once, and then we'll think about how to make your voice sound like the story! Should it be loud and exciting, or quiet and mysterious? Your voice helps tell the whole story!

slides.text: 'When you read to your audience, look up sometimes to make eye contact. Hold the book so they can see the pictures. Take your time — there is no rush.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When you read to your family, remember to look at them sometimes so they can see your happy face! And if your story has pictures, hold it up so they can see them too. Take your time, there's no need to rush.

slides.text: 'You are ready! Introduce what you are going to read: the title, the author (maybe YOU!), and why you chose it. Then read beautifully.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You're doing so great! Now, you get to tell everyone what you're going to read. Say the title and maybe who wrote it, and tell them why you picked this special story. Then, read it with all your heart!

slides.prompt: Read aloud to your family! Introduce your selection, read with expression and fluency, and share why this piece matters to you.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to read to your family! You'll tell them what you picked, read it with your super-duper voice, and share why it's so special to you. They are going to love listening to you read!

slides.text: 'You just shared the gift of reading with your family! Think about how far you have come this year — from learning letter sounds to reading aloud with confidence and expression.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read aloud with fluency, expression, and confidence? Can they introduce their selection and explain why they chose it?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read to your family and shared your special story. Remember at the beginning of the year when letters were tricky? Now look at you, reading with so much confidence and using your voice to make the story exciting! You are an amazing reader!

parent_notes: The reading celebration is a ritual of recognition. By reading aloud confidently to the family, the child demonstrates the full arc of their literacy development this year. Whether they read their own authored story, a favorite picture book, or a poem, the act of sharing literature aloud is powerful. Give the child your full, genuine attention. Respond to the CONTENT ('That part about the dog made me laugh!') as well as the performance ('Your reading voice was so expressive!'). If you have video from earlier in the year of the child's reading, compare it privately — the growth will be remarkable. This celebration frames reading not as a skill to be tested but as a gift to be shared — exactly the relationship with literacy that leads to lifelong reading.

title: Math Reflection — Creating a 'What I Know in Math' Book
description: The child creates a personal math book showcasing everything they have learned: number sense, all four operations, fractions, geometry, measurement, and problem-solving. This serves as both a review and a portfolio piece.
instructions:
1. 'You have learned SO MUCH math this year! Let's make a book that shows it all.'
2. Each page covers one topic:
   - Page 1: Numbers — 'I can read and write numbers to ____. My favorite number is ___ because ___.''
   - Page 2: Addition — show an example with drawing.
   - Page 3: Subtraction — show an example.
   - Page 4: Multiplication — show an example.
   - Page 5: Division — show an example.
   - Page 6: Fractions — draw fraction pictures.
   - Page 7: Geometry — draw and label shapes.
   - Page 8: Problem Solving — write and solve a word problem.
3. Illustrate each page.
4. Create a cover: 'What I Know in Math by [child's name].'
5. Read the book aloud.

slides.heading: Math Reflection
slides.subheading: My 'What I Know in Math' Book
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to make a super special book all about the amazing math you've learned. It's going to be like a treasure chest showing all the smart things your brain can do with numbers!

slides.setup_instructions: Stack paper for the book. Create a template outline showing what goes on each page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need some fun things to make our book! We need paper to write and draw on, a pencil to write with, colorful pencils to make it pretty, and a stapler to hold all our pages together. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these special tools for our math adventure?

slides.text: 'You are going to create a book showing EVERYTHING you know in math! Each page will cover one math topic with examples and pictures.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is how we start our amazing math book! We're going to fill up each page with something super cool you learned about math, like counting or shapes. It's like a special diary just for your math brain!

slides.text: 'Page 1: Numbers — write the biggest number you can. Page 2: Addition — show a problem and solve it. Page 3: Subtraction. Page 4: Multiplication. Page 5: Division.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to make pages for all the big math ideas! First, we'll write down numbers, then we'll show how we can add, take away, and even do some super-duper multiplication and division. It's like showing off your math superpowers!

slides.text: 'Page 6: Fractions — draw fraction pictures and write their names. Page 7: Geometry — draw and label all the shapes you know. Page 8: Write and solve a word problem!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're not done yet, there are more super math pages to make! We'll draw pictures for fractions, draw and name all the shapes we know, and even make up a fun math story problem to solve. You're going to show how much you know!

slides.text: 'Make each page colorful and clear. Add drawings. Create a cover. When you are done, you will have a math book that shows your whole year of learning!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's make our book look super awesome! We'll color all our pictures, make a cool cover that says your name, and then we'll have a book that shows off all the wonderful math you learned this year. It's going to be the best math book ever!

slides.prompt: Create your 'What I Know in Math' book. Complete at least 8 pages covering all the math you have learned. Illustrate, bind, and read it aloud.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make our math book! Let's start filling in each page with all the cool math things you know, like numbers and shapes and adding. We'll draw pictures and make it colorful, and when we're all done, we'll read our amazing math book together!

slides.text: 'Look at this book! You wrote about numbers, operations, fractions, and geometry. At the beginning of the year, you knew so much less. YOU built this mathematical knowledge, one lesson at a time.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate and explain their understanding of each major math topic? Which areas are strongest? Which are ready for elementary extension?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, look at your incredible math book! You filled it with numbers, adding, shapes, and so much more. You have learned so many wonderful things in math, and you built this book all by yourself, piece by piece. You are such a super mathematician!

parent_notes: The 'What I Know in Math' book serves dual purposes: it is a comprehensive review (the child must recall and demonstrate each concept) and a portfolio piece that documents year-end mathematical understanding. The process of EXPLAINING math in a book format deepens understanding — the child must organize their knowledge and present it clearly. Compare this book to the child's earliest math work from the beginning of the year (counting, number recognition) to see the extraordinary growth. This book also becomes a confidence-builder: when the child sees all their knowledge laid out in one place, they realize how much they have accomplished. Share it with grandparents, display it proudly, and keep it as a milestone marker.

title: Year Reflection — What I Learned and Who I Became
description: The child reflects on the entire year of learning: what they learned, how they grew, what challenged them, and what they are most proud of. They create a reflection page for the portfolio that captures their personal growth story.
instructions:
1. 'This year you learned and grew in so many ways! Today we reflect on YOUR story.'
2. Discussion prompts:
   - 'What is the most important thing you learned this year?'
   - 'What was the hardest thing you did? How did you overcome it?'
   - 'What are you most proud of?'
   - 'How have you changed since the beginning of the year?'
   - 'What do you want to learn next year?'
3. The child writes or dictates responses.
4. Create a 'Then and Now' comparison: what they could do in September vs. now.
5. Draw a picture of themselves as a learner.
6. 'You are not the same person you were at the start of the year — you are stronger, wiser, and more capable.'
materials_needed: Photos from the beginning of the year (optional)

slides.heading: Year Reflection
slides.subheading: What I Learned and Who I Became
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Year Reflection" and "What I Learned and Who I Became." It means we're going to think about all the super cool things you did and learned this whole school year!

slides.setup_instructions: Create a quiet, reflective space. Have early-year work samples available for comparison if possible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our special project! We have paper to draw on, pencils to write with, and colorful pencils to make it pretty. There's also a folder for your portfolio where we'll keep all your amazing work! Let's ask a grown-up to help you find everything.

slides.text: 'This year has been an incredible journey. You learned to read, to write, to solve math problems, to understand the world. Let's remember it all.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This year you learned so many new things, like reading stories and counting numbers! We're going to remember all the fun stuff we did together and how much you've grown. Let's think about all your adventures!

slides.text: 'What is the MOST IMPORTANT thing you learned this year? Not just a fact, but something that changed how you think or see the world.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think really hard. What's the MOST important thing you learned that made you think about things in a new way? It could be about being kind or figuring out a tricky puzzle!

slides.text: 'What was the HARDEST thing you did? And how did you get through it? That is called RESILIENCE — the ability to keep going when things are difficult.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes things are hard, right? What was something that felt super tricky for you, and what did you do to keep trying and finally do it? That's called being super strong, like a superhero!

slides.text: 'What are you MOST PROUD of? And what do you want to learn NEXT year? You are already looking forward — that is the sign of a true learner!'
slides.mascot_explanation: What's something you did this year that makes you feel super happy and proud of yourself? And what exciting new things do you want to learn when we start school again next year? You're always ready for more learning!

slides.prompt: Write your year reflection: what you learned, what challenged you, what you are proud of, and what you want to learn next. Draw a picture of yourself as a learner. Add it to your portfolio.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time to make your special reflection page! You can write or tell me what you learned, what was hard, what you're proud of, and what you want to learn next. Then, draw a picture of yourself as a super learner and put it in your portfolio folder.

slides.text: 'You have grown in every way this year — as a reader, a mathematician, a scientist, an artist, and most importantly, as a PERSON. I am so proud of you.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child articulate their growth over the year, identify specific achievements, and express goals for future learning?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You thought about all the amazing ways you grew this year, like a big, strong tree! You learned so much and became even more wonderful, and I am SO, SO proud of everything you accomplished!

parent_notes: This reflection is perhaps the most important 'lesson' of the year. It teaches the child to be metacognitive — to think about their own thinking and learning. The prompts are intentionally broad to let the child identify what mattered most to THEM, which may surprise you. Some children will name a specific academic achievement ('I learned to read chapter books!') while others will name a social or emotional milestone ('I learned to keep trying when something is hard.'). Both are equally valid. If you have early-year work samples, place them next to current work — the visual comparison of growth is powerful and emotional. The reflection page belongs at the front of the portfolio as a capstone. Write your own note to the child too — your words of pride and recognition become part of this record.

title: Read-Aloud: Ish by Peter H. Reynolds
description: Reading 'Ish' by Peter H. Reynolds, a story about a boy named Ramon who stops drawing after his brother laughs at his work, until his sister shows him that his art is wonderful in its own '-ish' way.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This boy loves to draw. Let's see what happens to his art.'
2. Read aloud — Ramon's joy, his brother's criticism, and his sister's rescue.
3. When Ramon crumples his drawings: 'How do you think he feels?'
4. When his sister shows her wall of saved drawings: 'What did she see in his art?'
5. Discuss '-ish': 'What does it mean for something to look vase-ish? Tree-ish?'
6. Celebrate imperfect art: it doesn't have to be exactly right to be wonderful.

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to read a special story today called 'Ish'! It's about a boy who really, really loves to draw pictures. Let's see what happens to his drawings in this story!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Set out drawing supplies for after.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our story, we need one very important thing: the book 'Ish'! Can you ask your grown-up to find the book so we can look at the pictures together? We'll also get some drawing things ready for later!

slides.text: Cover: 'Ramon loves to draw. But something happens that makes him want to stop. Let's find out what.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we see the cover of our book! This story is about a boy named Ramon, and he loves to draw so much. But then, something happens, and he almost stops drawing altogether. Let's read to find out why!

slides.text: Read with feeling — Ramon's joy, his hurt feelings, and his discovery of '-ish' thinking.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now we're going to read the story together. We'll use our best voices to show how happy Ramon is when he draws, how sad he feels when someone laughs, and how his sister helps him see things in a new way.

slides.text: Discuss: 'Why did Ramon stop drawing? What did his sister Marisol teach him? What does it mean to draw something -ish?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's talk about our story! Why do you think Ramon stopped drawing his pictures? And what did his sister Marisol teach him about his drawings? What do you think it means when we say something is "vase-ish" or "tree-ish"?

slides.prompt: Draw something '-ish'! A house-ish, a flower-ish, a cat-ish. It doesn't have to be perfect — it just has to feel right!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an artist, just like Ramon! We're going to draw something "-ish." You can draw a house-ish, or a flower-ish, or even a cat-ish! It doesn't have to look exactly perfect, just draw it how it feels to you.

slides.text: 'Your art doesn't have to be perfect. It just has to be YOURS. That's what makes it wonderful.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what '-ish' means and why it's a good way to think about art?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at your amazing drawing! You learned that your art doesn't have to be perfect to be super special. It's wonderful because it's yours, and that's the best part of all!

parent_notes: Peter H. Reynolds' 'Ish' is a powerful antidote to perfectionism. In Montessori, we value the process over the product, and this book reinforces that beautifully. It teaches that criticism can hurt but also that we can reframe our work positively. Pair with the companion book 'The Dot' for a full exploration of creative confidence.
